Gordon,
My Japanese plant books show tachi-aoi as a species of trillium.  The leaves are quite different from ones in an aoi mon and again the flowers don't match the ones on the bowl.  

The plant in the aoi mon is often called hollyhock in English, but that's yet another very different group of plants.  Working with the common names of plants is confusing enough without dealing with approximate translations, too.  Agreed that the vines don't belong to the leaves/mon.    

Jim



  Sorry, I just read Jim's discussion, but I think the plant used for the
  Tokugawa mon and that on this bowl is the tachi-aoe or hollyhock. Also, the
  vines and what not, are not tachi-aoe elements, but closer to karakusa or
  arabesques/foliage and are often found in lacquered pieces. I have a
  naginata pole with the same arabesques and mon (different mon). 



  Gordon
